Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
In the complex world of genetics, genes often collaborate in context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles and, consequently, impact disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A crucial aspect of understanding how genes influence complex traits lies in elucidating the regulation of gene expression across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential to pave the way for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the detection of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Despite these advancements, there remains a significant knowledge gap regarding the intricate interplay between genetic associations and gene expression patterns in highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this gap by employing a systems biology approach that combines gene co-expression, clustering of complex traits, therapeutic targets, and drug repurposing strategies.

Context: Genes work in concert through context-specific networks to execute various functions, and alterations in these genes can impact disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic grasp of gene expression regulation across diverse cell types.

Content: Previous research has identified different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. These mechanisms, when dysregulated, commonly lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: This manuscript addresses the knowledge gap in understanding how genes influence complex traits by focusing on the integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, result in tissue-specific pathology. By emphasizing this approach, our work aims to contribute to the development of improved treatments for diseases with complex genetic underpinnings.

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. response.output:
In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genes can significantly impact their functional roles, ultimately influencing disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Unraveling the intricate relationship between genes and complex traits necessitates a profound understanding of expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge, once acquired, has the potential to significantly enhance treatment strategies [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has shed light on various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has markedly improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue-specific and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, a significant knowledge gap remains in understanding how these genetic associations can be projected through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This is the critical gap that the current study aims to address.

Context: Genes operate within context-specific networks to carry out various cellular functions, and changes in these genes can impact disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic grasp of gene expression regulation across different cell types.

Content: Previous studies have identified different regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues. Integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms, which, when dysregulated, often result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. For instance, genetic variants can alter the functional role of genes, thereby affecting disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489; @doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890].

Conclusion: Despite these findings, a knowledge gap remains in understanding how gene expression regulation varies across different cell types and how this variation influences complex traits and disease susceptibility. The current manuscript aims to address this gap by investigating the role of context-specific gene networks and their impact on disease-relevant biological processes.

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to execute various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genetic sequences can significantly impact their functional roles, ultimately influencing disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A critical aspect of understanding how genes contribute to complex traits lies in elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential to enhance treatment options [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Furthermore, integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (genome-wide association studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has significantly improved the detection of transcriptional mechanisms. Disruptions in these mechanisms often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is a need for further research examining how gene co-expression patterns can highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which this manuscript aims to address.

Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various functions in a context-dependent manner [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. These genetic variations can influence disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].

Content: Understanding how genes impact complex traits relies on elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Conclusion: Despite these advances, a comprehensive understanding of how genes and their regulatory elements contribute to complex traits and tissue-specific pathology remains elusive. This manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by investigating the role of specific genetic variations in gene expression regulation and disease processes across various cell types and tissues.

response.output:
Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within context-specific networks to execute various biological roles [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional participation, ultimately impacting disease-relevant processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this framework, understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates elucidating the regulation of gene expression across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which could subsequently enhance treatment options [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Content: Previous investigations have identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the detection of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms frequently leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: Despite these advances, a comprehensive understanding of gene co-expression patterns and their implications for disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms, as well as identifying therapeutic targets and exploring drug repurposing opportunities. Additionally, the study will employ clustering of complex traits to enhance our grasp of the intricate relationship between genetics and disease.

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. response.output:
In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor genetic variations can alter these functional roles, ultimately impacting disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A deeper understanding of how genes influence complex traits hinges on elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge, in turn, should facilitate the development of more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (genome-wide association studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, the current understanding of gene co-expression patterns and their relationship to disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains incomplete.

This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. By employing a clustering approach for complex traits, we aim to identify therapeutic targets and explore opportunities for drug repurposing.

Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms.

Conclusion: Despite progress in identifying regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues, there is still a need to enhance our understanding of the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by presenting novel findings on the integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data, thereby improving our ability to identify transcriptional mechanisms underlying complex traits.

Content: TWAS functions by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has proven successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and has contributed to advancements in disease-risk prediction, known as polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success in individual gene-level analyses, it does not account for more intricate interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap presents an opportunity to further explore the complex interplay of genes and their role in human diseases, paving the way for a deeper understanding of disease mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success, it primarily focuses on individual gene-level associations, overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This limitation highlights a knowledge gap in understanding how complex gene co-expression patterns contribute to disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which this manuscript aims to address using a clustering approach for complex traits [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].

TWAS has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, contributing to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: Despite these advances, TWAS focuses on individual gene analysis, overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap underscores the need for complementary approaches that can elucidate complex disease mechanisms operating at the systems biology level.

With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS has emerged as an effective approach to identify disease-relevant biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. This method offers a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings at the individual gene level. However, one limitation of TWAS is its focus on single genes, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues, TWAS has emerged as an effective approach to identify disease-relevant biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. This method offers a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings at the individual gene level.

Conclusion: A limitation of TWAS is its focus on single genes, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap this manuscript addresses.

response.output:
Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are genetic methods that investigate whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the association between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have significantly contributed to understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]) and have proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). The increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]) has facilitated the application of TWAS, which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by introducing an innovative methodology that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at a systems level. This novel approach clusters complex traits ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), thereby enabling the identification of therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing efforts.

response.output:
Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a class of genetic analysis methods that aim to uncover the relationship between perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms and the association between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have been highly successful in several aspects, including understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]), and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). This success can be attributed to the availability of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]). Despite the success of TWAS in identifying gene-level associations, it does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

In this study, we propose to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns. Specifically, we aim to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms by integrating functional genomics data with TWAS findings. By clustering complex traits and identifying co-expressed genes, our approach will shed light on the network-level interactions that underlie human diseases. In doing so, we hope to uncover novel therapeutic targets for drug repurposing and development.

These approaches have been highly successful in several areas, including understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has made TWAS an attractive approach for identifying disease-associated biological processes. At its core, TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. Nonetheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which presents a limitation in capturing more intricate interactions at the network level.

In summary, while TWAS has proven valuable for identifying disease-associated genetic variants and interpreting their mechanisms through eQTLs integration, its focus on individual genes may overlook complex interactions at higher levels of organization within biological systems. Addressing this knowledge gap is crucial for a more comprehensive understanding of the intricate relationship between genetics, gene regulation, and human diseases.

Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in the field of functional genomics, elucidating disease etiology and informing drug development by examining the relationship between genetic variants and gene regulatory mechanisms. 

Content: TWAS approaches test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate associations between genetic variants and human diseases, proving successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk through polygenic scores, and repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367; @pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has facilitated the use of TWAS, which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success at the individual gene level, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level. The present manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by proposing a method that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms while considering intricate network-level interactions.

In summary, while TWAS has proven to be a powerful tool in identifying perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms associated with human diseases, its focus on individual genes means that it may not fully capture complex interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap underscores the need for further research and methodological development in this area.

Context: The increasing accessibility of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has paved the way for novel analytical methods to identify underlying biological processes. Conclusion: Notwithstanding these achievements, TWAS's focus on individual gene analysis may limit its ability to fully capture the complex interplay of genes within biological networks. This knowledge gap underscores the need for complementary methods that can elucidate higher-order gene interactions and further reveal disease etiology and drug mechanisms through functional genomics, such as gene co-expression analyses and clustering of complex traits. Addressing these challenges will contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of genetic associations and their implications for precision medicine.

response.output:
Context: The advent of gene expression data across numerous tissues has paved the way for sophisticated bioinformatics approaches to identify biological processes underlying human diseases. 

Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has achieved remarkable success in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has further proven beneficial in predicting disease risk (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level perturbations and does not account for more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires addressing complex interactions among genes within biological networks to better understand disease etiology and improve disease risk prediction, polygenic score calculations, and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. The present manuscript aims to contribute to this pressing need by proposing a novel approach that captures both individual gene effects and network-level interactions, thereby enhancing our comprehension of disease etiology and facilitating advancements in polygenic scores and drug repurposing.

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. response.output:
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes linked to genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has proven successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk through polygenic scores, and repurposing drugs [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level analysis, overlooking more intricate network-level interactions.

Conclusion: This study aims to address the knowledge gap in capturing complex interactions at the network level by clustering co-expressed genes and examining their associations with genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. By employing a systems biology approach, we expect to shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms from the perspective of gene co-expression and functional genomics, contributing to therapeutic targets and drug repurposing efforts.

Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has enabled the development of novel methods to identify biological processes associated with genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent approach is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which integrates expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has been successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and in applications such as disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level analysis and does not account for more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: This knowledge gap highlights the need for methods that can model complex genetic networks to better understand how perturbations in these systems contribute to disease susceptibility and progression. Our manuscript aims to address this issue by presenting a novel approach for investigating gene-gene interactions, paving the way for enhanced comprehension of disease etiology and improved risk prediction.

---
In the complex world of genetics, genes often collaborate in context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles and, consequently, impact disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A crucial aspect of understanding how genes influence complex traits lies in elucidating the regulation of gene expression across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential to pave the way for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the detection of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Despite these advancements, there remains a significant knowledge gap regarding the intricate interplay between genetic associations and gene expression patterns in highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this gap by employing a systems biology approach that combines gene co-expression, clustering of complex traits, therapeutic targets, and drug repurposing strategies.

---
In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genes can significantly impact their functional roles, ultimately influencing disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Unraveling the intricate relationship between genes and complex traits necessitates a profound understanding of expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge, once acquired, has the potential to significantly enhance treatment strategies [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has shed light on various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has markedly improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue-specific and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, a significant knowledge gap remains in understanding how these genetic associations can be projected through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This is the critical gap that the current study aims to address.

Context: Genes operate within context-specific networks to carry out various cellular functions, and changes in these genes can impact disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic grasp of gene expression regulation across different cell types.

Content: Previous studies have identified different regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues. Integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms, which, when dysregulated, often result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. For instance, genetic variants can alter the functional role of genes, thereby affecting disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489; @doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890].

Conclusion: Despite these findings, a knowledge gap remains in understanding how gene expression regulation varies across different cell types and how this variation influences complex traits and disease susceptibility. The current manuscript aims to address this gap by investigating the role of context-specific gene networks and their impact on disease-relevant biological processes.

In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to execute various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genetic sequences can significantly impact their functional roles, ultimately influencing disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A critical aspect of understanding how genes contribute to complex traits lies in elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential to enhance treatment options [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Furthermore, integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (genome-wide association studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has significantly improved the detection of transcriptional mechanisms. Disruptions in these mechanisms often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is a need for further research examining how gene co-expression patterns can highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which this manuscript aims to address.

Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various functions in a context-dependent manner [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. These genetic variations can influence disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].

Content: Understanding how genes impact complex traits relies on elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Previous research has identified different regulatory DNA elements, such as genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: Despite these advances, a comprehensive understanding of how genes and their regulatory elements contribute to complex traits and tissue-specific pathology remains elusive. This manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by investigating the role of specific genetic variations in gene expression regulation and disease processes across various cell types and tissues.

---
Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within context-specific networks to execute various biological roles [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional participation, ultimately impacting disease-relevant processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this framework, understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates elucidating the regulation of gene expression across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which could subsequently enhance treatment options [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Content: Previous investigations have identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the detection of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms frequently leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: Despite these advances, a comprehensive understanding of gene co-expression patterns and their implications for disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms, as well as identifying therapeutic targets and exploring drug repurposing opportunities. Additionally, the study will employ clustering of complex traits to enhance our grasp of the intricate relationship between genetics and disease.

---
Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various functions in a context-dependent manner [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. These genetic variations can impact disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6] and are crucial in understanding how genes influence complex traits.

Content: To elucidate the relationship between genes and these complex traits, it is essential to mechanistically understand gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Previous studies have identified different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: Despite these advancements, a significant knowledge gap remains in understanding how gene expression regulation influences complex traits and associated diseases. This manuscript aims to address this gap by investigating the role of specific regulatory DNA elements in disease-relevant biological processes. By doing so, we aim to contribute to the development of improved treatments for complex trait-associated diseases.

outputs.text:
Failed
---
In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor genetic variations can alter these functional roles, ultimately impacting disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A deeper understanding of how genes influence complex traits hinges on elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge, in turn, should facilitate the development of more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS (genome-wide association studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, the current understanding of gene co-expression patterns and their relationship to disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains incomplete.

This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. By employing a clustering approach for complex traits, we aim to identify therapeutic targets and explore opportunities for drug repurposing.

outputs.text: The increasing abundance of gene expression data across diverse tissues offers a valuable resource for exploring biological processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A powerful approach to dissect these processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of GWAS findings. TWAS functions by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This methodology has achieved remarkable success in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and has also proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes and understand disease etiology [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. 

Content: One such method, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), has proven successful in this regard by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS functions by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These TWAS approaches have not only contributed to understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in analyzing gene regulatory mechanisms at an individual level, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level, thereby addressing a critical knowledge gap in functional genomics and its potential impact on disease etiology and drug discovery.

---
With the increasing abundance of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9), a powerful approach to discern biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This method amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to furnish a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. TWAS operates by examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482]; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367), and it has achieved remarkable success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583]; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433). Furthermore, TWAS has proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). Nevertheless, TWAS functions at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes underlying human diseases. 

Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) (@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9). By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers a mechanistic interpretation for genetic associations uncovered by genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This approach tests whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms serve as mediators between genetic variants and diseases (@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367). Such efforts have significantly advanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level and contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) (@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w) and drug repurposing tasks (@doi:10.1038/nn.4618).

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success at the individual gene level, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level, which may further elucidate disease etiology and reveal novel therapeutic targets and strategies for drug repurposing. The current manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by employing a clustering of complex traits strategy within the functional genomics framework, focusing on gene co-expression patterns and their implications for genetic associations.

---
Context: The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various tissues offers a valuable resource for understanding biological processes and their implications in human diseases. 

Content: A prominent approach to leverage this data is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS provides a mechanistic interpretation for genetic association findings from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This method tests whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and disease risk [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk based on polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success, it primarily focuses on individual gene-level associations, overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This limitation highlights a knowledge gap in understanding how complex gene co-expression patterns contribute to disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which this manuscript aims to address using a clustering approach for complex traits [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].

Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for sophisticated bioinformatics analyses to identify biological processes underlying human diseases. 

Content: A notable approach in this regard is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which integrates expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Conclusion: Despite these advances, TWAS focuses on individual gene analysis, overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap underscores the need for complementary approaches that can elucidate complex disease mechanisms operating at the systems biology level.

However, as TWAS operates at the individual gene level, it may not capture more intricate interactions occurring at the network level.

outputs.text: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are genetic methods that examine whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective means to identify these biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level. This manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, thereby capturing complex interactions beyond the individual gene level.

---
Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a class of methods that aim to understand the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in several areas, including disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS has emerged as an effective approach to identify disease-relevant biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. This method offers a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings at the individual gene level. However, one limitation of TWAS is its focus on single genes, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are used to understand the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms.

Content: These approaches have been successful in several areas, including disease etiology at the transcriptome level, disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, and drug repurposing. With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues, TWAS has emerged as an effective approach to identify disease-relevant biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. This method offers a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings at the individual gene level.

Conclusion: A limitation of TWAS is its focus on single genes, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap this manuscript addresses.

Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are genetic methods that investigate whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the association between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have significantly contributed to understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]) and have proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). The increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]) has facilitated the application of TWAS, which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by introducing an innovative methodology that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at a systems level. This novel approach clusters complex traits ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), thereby enabling the identification of therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing efforts.

---
Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a class of genetic analysis methods that aim to uncover the relationship between perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms and the association between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have been highly successful in several aspects, including understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]), and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). This success can be attributed to the availability of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]). Despite the success of TWAS in identifying gene-level associations, it does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

In this study, we propose to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns. Specifically, we aim to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms by integrating functional genomics data with TWAS findings. By clustering complex traits and identifying co-expressed genes, our approach will shed light on the network-level interactions that underlie human diseases. In doing so, we hope to uncover novel therapeutic targets for drug repurposing and development.

---
Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a class of methods that test whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in several areas, including understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has made TWAS an attractive approach for identifying disease-associated biological processes. At its core, TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. Nonetheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which presents a limitation in capturing more intricate interactions at the network level.

In summary, while TWAS has proven valuable for identifying disease-associated genetic variants and interpreting their mechanisms through eQTLs integration, its focus on individual genes may overlook complex interactions at higher levels of organization within biological systems. Addressing this knowledge gap is crucial for a more comprehensive understanding of the intricate relationship between genetics, gene regulation, and human diseases.

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success at the individual gene level, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level. outputs.text:
Failed
---
Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a class of analytical methods that aim to understand the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in several applications, including elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS offers a valuable approach to identify biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions occurring at the network level.

In summary, while TWAS has proven to be a powerful tool in identifying perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms associated with human diseases, its focus on individual genes means that it may not fully capture complex interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap underscores the need for further research and methodological development in this area.

Context: The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has facilitated the development of novel methods to identify biological processes associated with genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent approach in this regard is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Although TWAS has achieved considerable success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and has proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], its reliance on individual gene analysis may overlook intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires a more comprehensive examination of genetic associations through gene expression patterns, which can highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms by capturing complex interactions among genes in molecular networks. This integrated approach will not only enhance our understanding of functional genomics but also facilitate the identification of novel therapeutic targets and repurposing opportunities for existing drugs, thereby contributing to advancements in precision medicine.

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has enabled the development of computational methods for identifying biological processes associated with genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent approach in this domain is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which integrates expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS determines if alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has achieved notable success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and in applications such as disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual genes, overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Despite the accomplishments of TWAS in interpreting GWAS findings and predicting disease risk, there remains a critical knowledge gap regarding the comprehension of complex interactions among genetic variants within biological networks. This manuscript aims to address this gap by proposing a novel approach that integrates systems biology and machine learning techniques to capture these elusive network-level interactions, thereby enhancing our understanding of the genetic architecture underlying human diseases.

Context: The advent of gene expression data across numerous tissues has paved the way for sophisticated bioinformatics approaches to identify biological processes underlying human diseases. 

Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has achieved remarkable success in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has further proven beneficial in predicting disease risk (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level perturbations and does not account for more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires addressing complex interactions among genes within biological networks to better understand disease etiology and improve disease risk prediction, polygenic score calculations, and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. The present manuscript aims to contribute to this pressing need by proposing a novel approach that captures both individual gene effects and network-level interactions, thereby enhancing our comprehension of disease etiology and facilitating advancements in polygenic scores and drug repurposing.

Context: The increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues offers a valuable resource for understanding complex biological processes and their implications in human diseases. A widely used approach, Transcription-Wide Association Studies (TWAS), has been successful in interpreting Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings by integrating expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data at the individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. However, this method does not account for higher-level interactions within gene networks.

Content: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This strategy has proven effective not only in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS, its focus on individual gene analysis leaves a gap in understanding more intricate interactions at the network level. This manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by employing a systems biology approach that combines genetic studies and functional genomics to investigate gene co-expression patterns, aiming to highlight disease etiology, therapeutic targets, and opportunities for drug repurposing, particularly in relation to complex traits clustering.

The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. One such approach is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings at the individual gene level. However, TWAS does not capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level. TWAS seeks to determine whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes linked to genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has proven successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk through polygenic scores, and repurposing drugs [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level analysis, overlooking more intricate network-level interactions.

Conclusion: This study aims to address the knowledge gap in capturing complex interactions at the network level by clustering co-expressed genes and examining their associations with genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. By employing a systems biology approach, we expect to shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms from the perspective of gene co-expression and functional genomics, contributing to therapeutic targets and drug repurposing efforts.

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has enabled the development of novel methods to identify biological processes associated with genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent approach is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which integrates expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings by examining individual genes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has been successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and in applications such as disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level analysis and does not account for more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: This knowledge gap highlights the need for methods that can model complex genetic networks to better understand how perturbations in these systems contribute to disease susceptibility and progression. Our manuscript aims to address this issue by presenting a novel approach for investigating gene-gene interactions, paving the way for enhanced comprehension of disease etiology and improved risk prediction.
